Award.AwardTitle: Atom-resolved microscopy of exotic superfluids in spin-imbalanced Fermi gases
Award.AbstractNarration:
Non-technical:
Superconductors, materials that have electrical currents that flow without losses, have important applications in building powerful electromagnets, sensitive sensors of magnetic fields and magnetic levitation devices. Understanding the behavior of superconductors in magnetic fields is crucial to building better superconducting devices. While large magnetic fields usually suppress superconductivity, they have also been predicted to lead to exotic superconducting phases of matter under the proper conditions. One such phase was proposed over fifty years ago, but has never been directly observed in any material. This research effort aims to discover this phase of matter in a gas of atoms cooled to very low temperatures. On the educational side, the project trains undergraduates, graduate students and a post-doctoral researcher in the techniques of ultracold gases. To complement the experimental effort, the principal investigator is developing and teaching a graduate course in ultracold atom physics, focusing on experimental techniques and potential applications. The course serves to train graduate students from the PI's lab in teaching through guest lecture opportunities.

Technical:
The competition between superconductivity and magnetism can give rise to exotic phases of quantum matter. Over fifty years ago, Fulde, Ferrell, Larkin and Ovchinnikov (FFLO) predicted a quantum phase where the Cooper pairs of a superconductor in a magnetic field condense at non-zero momentum. There has been indirect evidence for the existence of this phase in layered organic superconductors, heavy fermion materials and ultracold atomic gases, but a direct detection of its defining signatures has been elusive. The goal of this project is the direct detection of the FFLO phase in a superfluid atomic Fermi gas with spin imbalance. The research team uses atom-resolved in-situ imaging of the gas to search for its smoking gun signature: a spatial oscillation of the magnetization and superfluid gap that depends on the polarization of the gas. The search for this phase is conducted in a lower-dimensional lattice system where Fermi surface nesting effects are predicted to enhance the region of the phase diagram occupied by the FFLO phase. The team seeks to understand the low-temperature phase diagram of spin-imbalanced two-dimensional Fermi gases, use quantum gas microscopy to image imprinted solitonic lattices through the sharp variation of their magnetization and local density of states and apply these imaging techniques to search for FFLO in a thermal equilibrium state.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Materials in which the electrons interact strongly can exhibit fascinating phenomena such as magnetism and superconductivity. To optimally engineer the properties of these materials for technological applications requires a detailed understanding of the microscopic physics in the quantum regime. This presents a major challenge for numerical simulations on classical computers. In this project, we used an ultracold gas of fermionic atoms as a quantum simulator to study a range of phenomena in strongly interacting lattice systems. We focused in particular on the study of the Fermi-Hubbard model in and out of equilibrium. This is a paradigmatic model for strongly interacting lattice systems widely believed to capture the essential physics of high temperature superconductors. For our quantum simulations, we used a quantum gas microscope, an apparatus that allows us to take snapshots of a quantum many-particle system with single-atom and single-site resolution.

Over the course of this project, we made several discoveries. The most important of those was the discovery that the resistivity of a Fermi-Hubbard system varies linearly with temperature for a certain density of atoms in the lattice. This unusual behavior has been observed in many materials with strongly interacting electrons including cuprate superconductors in their normal (non-superconducting) state. The physics responsible for this behavior is still not understood and it is speculated that the normal state of the cuprates holds the key to unlocking their mystery. Our experimental demonstration that the Fermi-Hubbard model can give rise to similar phenomenology gives hope of obtaining a microscopic understanding of this physics. Continuing in the theme of charge transport, we studied Hubbard systems subjected to large effective electric fields and discovered an unusual regime where charge perturbations relax very slowly because they are bottlenecked by a coupled transport of heat in the system.

Other highlights of this project include the observation of an unusual form of antiferromagnetism (canted antiferromagntism) in Fermi-Hubbard systems subjected to a high effective magnetic field and the observation of charge density waves in Hubbard systems with attractive interactions. We have also developed a technique for studying single-particle excitations in Hubbard systems. This technique can be used to probe precursors to superconductivity. Finally, we experimentally demonstrated a method to introduce long-range interactions in lattice Fermi gases based on coupling the atomic ground state to highly excited electronic states known as Rydberg states. This enabled the quantum simulation of a new class of electronic models with off-site interactions.

Taken together, these advances in the quantum simulation of interacting fermionic lattice systems will lead to an improved understanding of quantum materials useful for society.
